newsitem.title: USA: Investors to feast on new US corporate debt issues.
newsitem.headline: Investors to feast on new US corporate debt issues.

text.p: Hungry investors are expected to feast on a bounty of new corporate debt offerings as the list of deals continues to grow, dealers said.
Philip Morris was expected to top Tuesday's menu with a $500 million A2/A rated 30-year debt offering via Merrill Lynch & Co, expected to price, sources said.
Price talk on the issue was seen between 100 and 103 basis points over comparable U.S. Treasuries.

High-grade syndicate sources said they heard talk on Tuesday that US West Inc unit, US West Capital Funding, would increase the size of its planned $2.0 billion four-part debt offering by adding another tranche.
"Talk in the market is that the issuer added an additional tranche consisting of a century bond to the offering," said one syndicate source.
The A2/BBB-plus rated deal is now rumord to come in between $2.25 and $3.0 billion, syndicate sources added.
Current price talk on US West Capital's offering is as follows, syndicate sources said.
-five-year, 55 to 60 basis points over Treasuries.
-10-year, 80 to 85 basis points over Treasuries.
-30-year, 110 basis points over Treasuries.
-40-year, put seven, 55 to 60 basis points over Treasuries.
*100-year bond is rumored to be added but the amount was not immediately available.
In addition, Quebecor Printing is expected to tap the market with its first-time ever debt offering, sources said.
The $150 million BBB-plus/Baa1 rated 10-year issue is expected to be underwritten by Goldman Sachs & Co may price as early as Thursday, dealers said.
"This is Quebecor's first time in the market," said one high-grade source.
The issue is expected to be noncallable for life.
Meanwhile, with the improved tone in the Treasury market, dealers said, issuers are likely to tap the market now as the financing environment becomes cheaper.
Currently, the long bond is up 26/32 at 96-11/32 to yield 6.79 percent compared with 6.85 percent at Monday's close.

Last Friday, a stronger-than-expected U.S. jobs report triggered about a two-point drop in the price of the benchmark 30-year Treasury bond, driving yields sharply higher and sending issuers to the sidelines.

Among other issues, Bank Nationale de Paris is expected to issue $350 million in either 10 or 12-year subordinated notes via Salomon Brothers. The deal is expected to be launched on Wednesday, syndicate sources said.
Leucadia National Corp is also expected tap the market with a $150 million 30-year capital securities deal with a ten-year call, dealers said.
Also, BankAmerica Corp is expected to tap the market with $450 million in A1/A-minus rated trust preferred securities due 2026.
TCI Communications Inc is preparing a $500 million trust preferred securities deal for one day this week via Lehman Brothers, sources said.
Baxter International is expected to tap the market with a two-part $450 million A3/A rated debt offering via Goldman Sachs & Co.
The deal is expected to consist of a $250 million 10-year issue and $200 million in 30-year debt, sources said.
High-yield issuers are also expected to remain busy with offerings, dealers said.
CFP Holdings is expected to tap the 144A market with $110 million in seven-year guaranteed senior notes via NationsBank Capital Markets.
Imperial Credit Industries Inc is expected to issue $175 million in B1/B-plus rated 144A senior notes due 2007 via Lehman Brothers.
Vintage Petroleum is expected to set $100 million in 12-year senior subordinated notes via Salomon Brothers.
Electronic Retailing Systems International Inc is expected to bring $100 million (proceeds) in 144A senior discount notes ue 2004 via CS First Boston.
LDM Technologies Inc is expected to issue $100 million in 144A senior subordinated notes due 2007 via Smith Barney.
Tenet HealthCare is expected to bring a three-part debt offering consisting of $200 million in notes due 2003 and $600 million in notes due 2005 and $500 million in notes due 2007, sources said.
The deal is expected to be underwritten by Donaldson Lufkin & Jenrette Securities.
--Nancy Leinfuss, 212-859-1675
